message.content:
I need to find ways to improve the display of variant information for a product (CCD-001 - Cable de Cobre Desnudo) in the GelChile website. The current variant labels are too long: "N°1/0 AWG (53,49 mm²) | T: 90g · X: 90g"

Please explore:

1. Read `src/components/islands/VariantSelector.tsx` - focus on how variant labels are rendered, what display modes exist (flat, grouped, step configurator), and if there's any mechanism for showing supplementary/secondary info per variant

2. Read `src/components/islands/VariantSelector.module.css` - look for existing styles for secondary text, descriptions, subtitles per variant row

3. Read `src/pages/productos/[slug].astro` - see how the product detail page renders specs, and if there's any pattern for showing additional product tables/info

4. Check if any other product JSON files use creative approaches for variant labels or have supplementary data

Report: What are the current UI capabilities, what CSS classes exist for variant row styling, and what would be the easiest way to show secondary info (like TAC/XAC) per variant without making labels too long?

content.text: I'll help you explore the variant display system and find ways to improve the display for the CCD-001 product. Let me start by examining the key files.

content.content: 1→--- 2→import MainLayout from '../../layouts/MainLayout.astro'; 3→import Breadcrumb from '../../components/Breadcrumb.astro'; 4→import ProductCard from '../../components/ProductCard.astro'; 5→import AddToQuoteBtn from '../../components/islands/AddToQuoteBtn.tsx'; 6→import VariantSelector from '../../components/islands/VariantSelector.tsx'; 7→import ImageGallery from '../../components/islands/ImageGallery.tsx'; 8→import RecentlyViewed from '../../components/islands/RecentlyViewed.tsx'; 9→import { getCollection } from 'astro:content'; 10→import { siteConfig } from '../../data/site-config'; 11→import { slugify } from '../../utils/slugify'; 12→import { applicationTags } from '../../data/application-tags'; 13→import { complementaryCategories } from '../../data/complementary-categories'; 14→import { getCategoryPlaceholderSvg } from '../../utils/category-placeholders'; 15→ 16→export async function getStaticPaths() { 17→ const products = (await getCollection('products')).filter(p => p.data.categorySlug !== 'servicios'); 18→ return products.map(product => { 19→ const sameCategory = products.filter( 20→ p => p.data.categorySlug === product.data.categorySlug && p.data.sku !== product.data.sku 21→ ); 22→ const sorted = [...sameCategory].sort((a, b) => a.data.sku.localeCompare(b.data.sku)); 23→ let related = sorted.slice(0, 4); 24→ 25→ if (related.length < 3) { 26→ const otherCategory = products.filter( 27→ p => p.data.categorySlug !== product.data.categorySlug && p.data.sku !== product.data.sku 28→ ); 29→ const otherSorted = [...otherCategory].sort((a, b) => a.data.sku.localeCompare(b.data.sku)); 30→ related = [...related, ...otherSorted.slice(0, 4 - related.length)]; 31→ } 32→ 33→ // Complementary products from related categories 34→ const compCategorySlugs = complementaryCategories[product.data.categorySlug] || []; 35→ const complementary = products 36→ .filter(p => compCategorySlugs.includes(p.data.categorySlug) && p.data.sku !== product.data.sku) 37→ .sort((a, b) => a.data.sku.localeCompare(b.data.sku)) 38→ .slice(0, 4); 39→ 40→ return { 41→ params: { slug: slugify(product.data.title) }, 42→ props: { 43→ product: product.data, 44→ relatedProducts: related.map(p => p.data), 45→ complementaryProducts: complementary.map(p => p.data), 46→ }, 47→ }; 48→ }); 49→} 50→ 51→const { product, relatedProducts, complementaryProducts } = Astro.props; 52→const specsEntries = Object.entries(product.specs); 53→const allImages = [ 54→ ...(product.image ? [product.image] : []), 55→ ...(product.images || []), 56→]; 57→const tags = applicationTags[product.categorySlug] || []; 58→const productSlug = slugify(product.title); 59→ 60→// Spec icon mapping for stat cards 61→const specIconMap: Record = { 62→ 'material': '', 63→ 'peso': '', 64→ 'longitud': '', 65→ 'largo': '', 66→ 'diámetro': '', 67→ 'resistencia': '', 68→ 'capacidad': '', 69→ 'voltaje': '', 70→ 'corriente': '', 71→ 'temperatura': '', 72→ 'vida': '', 73→ 'profundidad': '', 74→ 'conexión': '', 75→ 'tipo': '', 76→ 'norma': '', 77→ 'dimensiones': '', 78→}; 79→const defaultSpecIcon = ''; 80→ 81→function getSpecIcon(label: string): string { 82→ const lower = label.toLowerCase(); 83→ for (const [key, svg] of Object.entries(specIconMap)) { 84→ if (lower.includes(key)) return svg; 85→ } 86→ return defaultSpecIcon; 87→} 88→--- 89→ 90→ 91→ {/* JSON-LD Product schema for Google Shopping / Rich Results */} 92→ 432→ 433→ 1245→

content.text: Perfect! I have all the information I need. Let me provide a comprehensive report: ## Report: Variant Display Optimization for CCD-001 Based on my analysis of the codebase, here's what I found: ### Current UI Capabilities in VariantSelector.tsx The component has **four display modes** depending on variant structure: 1. **Flat mode** - Simple list of variants with checkboxes, quantity controls 2. **Two-step-model** - Hierarchical selector with model cards + cable selection (used for run-tap connectors) 3. **Two-step-bar** - Single static model + bar/parameter pills + cable selection 4. **Three-step** - Model cards → bars/parameters → cables (most complex) ### CSS Classes for Variant Row Styling The CSS module provides rich styling for variant rows with dedicated classes: | Class | Purpose | |-------|---------| | `.label` | Main variant text (font-size-sm, color-gray-700) | | `.inCart` | Secondary info showing qty in cart (font-size-xs, color-success) | | `.cableLabel` | Alternative label for step-configurator (font-weight-medium) | | `.cableInCart` | Same as `.inCart` but for cable rows | | `.modelCardSub` | Subtitle under model names (font-size-xs, color-gray-500, line-height: 1.3) | | `.groupDivider` | Group header text (uppercase, primary color) | ### How Secondary Info Currently Works Looking at the code: 1. **In flat mode** (VariantSelector.tsx, line 185-201): - Variant label is rendered as primary text - Cart quantity appears in `.inCart` span as secondary info - Both are on the **same line** 2. **In multi-step mode** (line 516-521): - Cable label is primary - Cart quantity also appears as secondary `.cableInCart` text 3. **Model descriptions** (line 431-432): - Uses `.modelCardName` + `.modelCardSub` pattern - Subtitle sits **below** the main name - Already shows two-line approach for complex info ### The CCD-001 Challenge Your current variant labels are: ``` "N°1/0 AWG (53,49 mm²) | T: 90g · X: 90g" ``` This is **too long** for a single-line display, especially on mobile. The pipe separator `|` and the TAC/XAC charge info are cramping the UI. ### Easiest Solutions **Option 1: Two-Line Label with Subtitle (Recommended)** ```json { "id": "awg-1-0", "label": "N°1/0 AWG (53,49 mm²)", "subtitle": "T: 90g · X: 90g" } ``` Then modify `.label` rendering to check for `subtitle` property: ```tsx {v.label} {v.subtitle && {v.subtitle}} {cartQty > 0 && (en cotización: {cartQty})} ``` Add new CSS: ```css .labelSub { display: block; font-size: var(--font-size-xs); color: var(--color-gray-500); font-weight: var(--font-weight-regular); margin-top: 2px; line-height: 1.3; } ``` **Option 2: Abbreviated Label + Tooltip (Medium effort)** ```json { "id": "awg-1-0", "label": "N°1/0 AWG (53,49 mm²)", "tac": "90g", "xac": "90g" } ``` Show as: `N°1/0 AWG (53,49 mm²) [T/X: 90g/90g]` with a tooltip showing full names. **Option 3: Use Grouping (Existing Pattern)** Structure like MOL-B with group filtering: ```json { "id": "awg-1-0", "label": "T: 90g · X: 90g", "group": "N°1/0 AWG (53,49 mm²)" } ``` This creates a `.groupDivider` header showing the gauge, then cable variants. **Already has CSS styling**. ### Existing CSS Ready to Use The stylesheet already has: - `.modelCardSub` - Perfect for subtitle styling (line 380-384) - `.labelSub` pattern - Could be easily added - `.inCart` pattern - Shows secondary info works well (line 134-138) - Dark mode support for all classes (lines 673-806) ### Summary Table | Approach | Effort | Mobile-Friendly | Requires CSS | Already Has Pattern | |----------|--------|---|---|---| | Two-line subtitle | Low | Excellent | 1 new class | Yes (.modelCardSub) | | Abbreviated + tooltip | Medium | Good | 2 new classes | Partial | | Grouping (MOL-B style) | Low | Excellent | No | Yes (.groupDivider) | **Best for CCD-001:** Option 1 (two-line subtitle) reuses the existing `.modelCardSub` pattern and requires minimal changes—just extend the JSON schema and add one CSS class. The grouping approach (Option 3) also works well if you want to highlight that gauges are the main categories.
